qas.question: What did Aristotle define as distinct from matter?

plausible_answers.text: to an actual independent thing in itself

qas.question: How does Descartes use matter and the formal/forming principle?

context: For Descartes, matter has only the property of extension, so its only activity aside from locomotion is <b3_0>to exclude other bodies<b3_0/>: this is the <b0_0>mechanical<b0_0/> philosophy. Descartes makes an absolute distinction between <b1_0>mind<b1_0/>, which he defines as unextended, thinking substance, and matter, which he defines as unthinking, extended substance. They are independent things. In contrast, Aristotle defines matter and the formal/forming principle <b4_0>as complementary principles<b4_0/> that together compose one independent thing (substance). In short, Aristotle defines matter (roughly speaking) as what things are actually made of (with a potential independent existence), but Descartes elevates matter <b2_0>to an actual independent thing in itself<b2_0/>.
